may have to upload it directly to the Files section of this group in 
order for people to be able to get it.  Right now we can't see what

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Richard Gong <gongrichard@y...> wrote:
> I made this simple program that doesn't realistically
> simulate gravity, but it uses this thing I call the
> mattress. Which is basically just like a layer of
> numbers, that tells you the contours of a space time
> continuum (shows up as degrees of green, more green =
> more gravity). Gravity spreads out in waves,
> propagating from point to point, although it's not
> probably an accurate description of actual waves. Then
> there's this second layer that tells u how much mass
> you have (red). And the mass gravitates towards the
> spots of depression.
>  
> My guess is a mattress layer is just as good as neural
> networks. The brain is kinda a lazy thing that finds
> its way to the lowest valley in a plane.
>  
> Weird thing is whenever I put something in there
> that's not really very illogical, like the mass slowly
> fades away, or like the gravity light cone is made of
> integers and eventually lose value, then there are
> these black spots that appear, and it looks like Alife
> a lot.
